Dear Ms. Bejcek:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
10/1/18. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational statewide
automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the primary
tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
The agency did not upload all required documents into MiSACWIS. This is a repeat
violation. A corrective action plan is required.
ISEP 6.18 Page 23 Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative foster parents within 180
days of the date of placement.
One of seven relative caregivers reviewed was licensed in excess of 180 days. A
corrective action plan is required.
ISEP 5.1 – Page 14 Caseload Progressions for New Employees (Commitment
23).
b. For foster care and adoption workers, three training cases may be assigned on or
after day one of pre-service training at the supervisor’s discretion using CWTI case
assignments guidelines. After completion of week three of pre-service training, up to
five total cases may be assigned with supervisory approval using CWTI case
assignment guidelines. Final caseload may be assigned after nine weeks.
One new foster care worker was assigned 5 cases on the last day in the 9th week of
training exceeding 5 total cases. A corrective action plan is required.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08C Page 2 Required Participation in Development - Parents
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and service agreement, the parent
is given a copy for review. Foster care work-ers need to ensure the parent understands
all areas within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older must sign the PATP.
If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must
4

identify and document additional action needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the PATP. As the goals are
achieved, modified or expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents and
youths age 14 and older must participate in the development of each updated treatment
plan, allowing for opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
Nineteen service plans were reviewed. One caregiver PATP and two birth parent
PATPs were signed more than 30 days after the end of the report period. A corrective
action plan is required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
DCWL Analyst Report Findings
The assigned analyst between 9/4/18 and 9/20/18 visited three foster parents and
three unlicensed relatives. Seven foster children were observed. Three birth parents
were contacted. The following concerns were reported.
5

Concern # 1.
One parent report they did not sign the service plan. The agency responded that the
parent refused to sign the service plan. This was documented in the case file and
court record.
One parent said she was not involved in the medical decisions concerning her child.
The agency responded that reports reflect many efforts to engage the parent
evidenced by contacts by assigned case managers. The children have been in care
since 12/29/16. The goal for her children changed in December 2017. Three of her
children were changed to a goal of full custody with their fathers. One child’s goal
was changed to adoption at this time. One child was removed from her 1/22/18 and
two other children were removed 3/16/18. At removal from the fathers, the goal was
changed to guardianship. Two previous complaints of similar nature were received
by the agency from the mother, but it was found there was no evidence to support
her concerns.
One parent said she was not invited to medical appointments, school meetings or
emergencies involving her child. The agency responded, this complaint was
received by the department from the parent in the summer of 2018 after her parental
rights were terminated/goal changed. The assigned case manager reports that the
parent never asked for medical information and at that time the goal had been
changed. She was provided with all the children’s medical information at the time
and she again refused to sign. She had refused to sign all medical passports
previously as reported by the assigned case manager. There are contacts in
January and February 2017 that indicate attempts to complete the medical passport.
The parent has never requested to be at medical appointments or get information
from school but was made aware of them. The supervisor when the complaint was
received had a conversation with the parent instructing her that she can call the
school or medical provider at any time to get information. She has not done this. The
parent is present at FTMs and all hearings and it was not a voiced concern until after
her rights were terminated/goal changed.
One parent said she is not involved in decisions regarding the physical appearance
of her child. The agency responded the parent has signed for ear piercing for one of
the girls. The fathers are involved with the children have provided approvals for
haircuts. The birth mother has not previously expressed this complaint.
One parent said the foster care does only visited her home one time since 2017. The
agency responded the assigned case manager documented efforts to go to the
home and the mother would not answer the door. Another case manager went to the
home in March 2018 and was able to see the parent in her home. The goal changed
so there was not longer the requirement to visit in her home.
One parent said she is not offered weekly visitation. Visits are scheduled every two
weeks.
Concern #2
6

There were no concerns reported.
Concern #3
One parent does not feel supported or respected by the foster care worker. The
agency responded that the analyst visited with the bio parents on 9/13/18. The goal
was changed to adoption and parental rights were terminated on 9/12/18. That
would be a difficult time for the parents and it would be reasonable for them to feel
this way at the time. Reports throughout the time the case was in reunification
status document efforts to reduce the barriers and reunify the family.
Concern #4
The relative care giver was not offered the option of becoming licensed. The agency
responded that the children were placed in the relative home on 8/6/18. The date of
the analyst visit was 9/6/18. The 3130A was also completed on 9/6/18. They were
referred for licensure 9/19/18 and a private agency is currently working with the
family on the licensing process.
Concern #5
One foster parent said the foster care worker does not make unannounced visits.
The agency responded unannounced home visits were done on 5/1/18, 8/10/18 and
9/20/18.
One foster parent said a foster child does not have month sib visits. The agency
responded the child does not have any siblings.
Concern #6
One relative caregiver was not made aware of financial assistance. The agency
responded the caregiver did sign the DHS-972 on 6/8/18 with CPS for placement
and a licensing worker talked with her to complete the 3130A on 7/3/18 and 7/18/18
to review the finances as well as benefits available to her in becoming licensed.
One relative caregiver did not sign the service plan. The agency responded the
caregiver signed the PATP on 8/9/18 and 10/23/18.
One relative caregiver is not notified of FTMs. The agency responded that the
caregiver was in attendance at the FTM on 9/28/18, which was after her meeting
with DCWL on 9/20/18. The only other FTM was the removal FTM that CPS would
have held on 6/14/18. It did not appear the caregiver was in attendance for that
meeting.
One parent said he did not sign the service plan or participate in its development.
The agency responded that the parent has a traumatic brain injury and lives with his
7

mother the caregiver. The parent attends several group therapies throughout the
week that help integrate him into the community. He is unable to care for his child
independently and requires a caregiver himself, which is why he lives with his
mother. He functions at about the level of a 4-year-old. He did not attend the FTMs
and this likely the reasoning.
One parent said he has not participated in any FTMs. The agency responded with
the above comments.
The annual review was completed on 10/31/17. The following rule, policy and
ISEP violations were issued.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency,
and the other parties involved in providing needed
services, or medical care, unless the agency documents
why any of the entities have not been involved.
Seventeen service plans were reviewed. One youth over 14
years did not sign the PATP.
The 2018 renewal inspection found two birth parents signed
their PATP more than 30 days after the end of the report period.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the foster parents
to understand the plan for the child and the foster parent's
role in assisting the agency in carrying out the plan.
Seventeen service plans were reviewed. Five care givers signed
the PATP more than one month after the end of the service plan
period. Four care givers did not sign the PATP.
The 2018 renewal inspection found one foster parent signed
their PATP more than 30 days after the end of the report
period..
8

ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational
statewide automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which
will be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
This consultant found nine documents that should have been uploaded into
MiSACWIS across six foster care cases during the early part of the review period.
The agency was able to upload all required documents into MiSACWIS for second
half of the review period.
The 2018 renewal inspection found six documents not uploaded into MiSACWIS.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective
action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
